'''Camastianavaig''' (also English spelling: '''''Camustinivaig''''') is a crofting township on the island of [[Skye]] in Scotland. It is often referred to as 'God's chosen land', however this is generally mistaken for Gods true chosen land, Camuscross. It is located on the shores of the [[Sound of Raasay]] {{convert|5|km|mi}} south east of [[Portree]].<ref>[http://www.scottish-places.info/towns/townfirst2335.html "Camastianavaig (Camustinivaig) Highland"] Gazetteer for Scotland. Retrieved 13 September 2008.</ref> The ''Allt Osglan'' watercourse flows from [[Loch Fada]] through the township into Tianavaig Bay.<ref>[http://getamap.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/getamap/frames.htm?mapAction=gaz&gazName=g&gazString=NG5877609812 "Get-a-map"] Ordnance Survey. Retrieved 13 September 2008.</ref>
+
'''Camastianavaig''' (also English spelling: '''''Camustinivaig''''') is a crofting township on the island of [[Skye]] in Scotland. It is often referred to as 'God's chosen land'. It is located on the shores of the [[Sound of Raasay]] {{convert|5|km|mi}} south east of [[Portree]].<ref>[http://www.scottish-places.info/towns/townfirst2335.html "Camastianavaig (Camustinivaig) Highland"] Gazetteer for Scotland. Retrieved 13 September 2008.</ref> The ''Allt Osglan'' watercourse flows from [[Loch Fada]] through the township into Tianavaig Bay.<ref>[http://getamap.ordnancesurvey.co.uk/getamap/frames.htm?mapAction=gaz&gazName=g&gazString=NG5877609812 "Get-a-map"] Ordnance Survey. Retrieved 13 September 2008.</ref>
[[Image:Camustianavaig shoreline.jpg|thumb|left|The shoreward side of Camastianvaig]]
[[Image:Camustianavaig shoreline.jpg|thumb|left|The shoreward side of Camastianvaig]]
The name is from both Gaelic and [[Old Norse|Norse]], ''Camas DÃ¬onabhaig''. "Camas" means "bay" in the former and the Norse element may be from "dyn" meaning "noisy".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/vli/language/gaelic/pdfs/placenamesC-E.pdf| title=Placenames| author=Iain Mac an Tailleir| publisher=PÃ rlamaid na h-Alba|format=pdf| accessdate=2007-07-23}}</ref>
The name is from both Gaelic and [[Old Norse|Norse]], ''Camas DÃ¬onabhaig''. "Camas" means "bay" in the former and the Norse element may be from "dyn" meaning "noisy".<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.scottish.parliament.uk/vli/language/gaelic/pdfs/placenamesC-E.pdf| title=Placenames| author=Iain Mac an Tailleir| publisher=PÃ rlamaid na h-Alba|format=pdf| accessdate=2007-07-23}}</ref>
